children.name: At this time, external teams are welcome to contribute to TastySoft in the '/ReactComponents/ParchmentComponents' directory. Anything outside of this directory is not open for external contributions. Please reach out to the TastySoft team if you have any questions or concerns - or need to request a feature or bug fix to CoreComponents.
Our preferred directory structure is accurately outlined
Storybook is configured with an Accessibility Feedback plugin and it updates with each hot load while developing. Accessibility concerns flagged with this tool will be immediate PR blockers.

Internationalization, in general, is solved by implementing a "languagePack" prop which accepts a string map and assigns it to appropriate elements within the component. As a result, string values meant to be read by users or screen readers should
be statically set values. This includes ARIA attributes, as they are meant to be read by screen readers.
If you need help solving accessibility or internationalization concerns, please don't hesitate to reach out to the TastySoft team!

As a core philosophy, all component CSS should be internal to the component and can optionally be conditional based on a component prop. An implementor should never be required to write CSS to achieve a design. This includes correctly implementing breakpoints and applying necessary style properties.
This includes subtle animations where appropriate, and disabling those animations for users which fit the "prefers-reduced-motion: reduced" media-query.
Built in accessibility and tooling to prevent a11y mistakes, such as TypeScript and forcing errors around "disabled".

Most Design Systems have a tooltip component. They also have buttons. To build a button with a tooltip in those design systems, the developer needs to implement both. In the TastySoft design system, we created a button with tooltipText="I'm a tooltip!" and the implementation is simplified. At scale this simplification is magnified greatly.

Instead of relying on implementors to style components or component variations, the TastySoft Design System comes pre-baked with the styles our designs will demand. Any variants of those components are controlled with simple props. This also serves Ease of Use. In general, aim to build a component so that it has value to a developer that has never even heard of CSS. Think "Smart Components".

Props should rely on simple data structures and callbacks. Filtering and sorting should be internal to the component. More complex framework tooling should also come baked inside of components and any variations in those behaviors should be controlled by simple props.
Composition vs Opinionated Styling and Behavior
Composition vs Opinionated Styling and Behavior

Composition architecture should be (mostly) avoided. This is an art and not a science - the lines between these concepts, Compasability and Opinionated Design, are often blurred. Bear in mind that extreme composability creates inconsistencies in our applications. Extremely opinionated components limit their use-cases. There is a balance, but for an organization that values consistency, the business need is heavily swayed towards opinionated design. If there is a viable, opinionated approach, then that's the preferred solution. To make component architecture even more complex, also keep in mind that too many prop controls around style variations and/or behavior puts the component at risk of having broken configurations.

Don't use them. Write your own solutions, please. We have very rare exceptions to this rule, such as "react-pdf", but these exceptions will require a fair degree of time to approve and vet. The Tasty team has worked very hard at removing some legacy implementations of 3PLs and the rewards have been plentiful!
GitHub actions uses a security scan throughout the pipeline. Newly implemented security flags will block your deployment.

Be sure to add the GitHub "@parchment-io/tasty-soft" team to your pull request and please be patient to allow for a member of TastySoft to approve before merging to QA. And, as always, be sure to check the pipeline!
